docs.snippet: LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, is wondering who speaks for the Bush Administration on farm policy - Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, or Clayton Yeutter, the Secretary of Agriculture.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, is wondering who speaks for the Bush Administration on farm policy - Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, or Clayton Yeutter, the Secretary of Agriculture.

docs.snippet: LEAD: When Brazil's armed forces toppled President Joao Goulart in 1964, they were no less intent on ousting the powerful man behind the throne, Leonel Brizola, a crowd-pleasing Socialist who had dreams of succeeding his brother-in-law in elections...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: When Brazil's armed forces toppled President Joao Goulart in 1964, they were no less intent on ousting the powerful man behind the throne, Leonel Brizola, a crowd-pleasing Socialist who had dreams of succeeding his brother-in-law in elections the following year.

headline.main: Army's Old Foe Rides High in Brazil

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Top American trade negotiators met today with officials of the European Community for talks that are expected to focus on the contentious issue of farm subsidies.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Top American trade negotiators met today with officials of the European Community for talks that are expected to focus on the contentious issue of farm subsidies.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Even before the Olympic torch arrived in Seoul, South Korea, last year, the coach of the United States boxing team, Ken Adams, knew who might get burned. Two days before the opening ceremony, Adams sat in an upstairs room in the Olympic Village...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Even before the Olympic torch arrived in Seoul, South Korea, last year, the coach of the United States boxing team, Ken Adams, knew who might get burned. Two days before the opening ceremony, Adams sat in an upstairs room in the Olympic Village and talked about how many gold medals his boxers might earn.

headline.main: Roy Jones Jr. Still Fighting For the Gold

docs.snippet: LEAD: As they prepare for their annual planting, farmers in the Sacramento Valley in northern California, the American Rice Bowl, are trying again to see if there is a way to open Japan's tightly sealed rice market.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As they prepare for their annual planting, farmers in the Sacramento Valley in northern California, the American Rice Bowl, are trying again to see if there is a way to open Japan's tightly sealed rice market.

headline.main: U.S. Rice Farmers Pressing Again For Entry Into the Japanese Market

docs.snippet: LEAD: OF THE NEW GUATEMALA IS WORKING for anyone, it is working for Enrique de Leon. His unpretentious steakhouse in the capital has proved very successful, and he is investing the profits in a new and far more elegant eatery called Vivaldi, where a...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: OF THE NEW GUATEMALA IS WORKING for anyone, it is working for Enrique de Leon. His unpretentious steakhouse in the capital has proved very successful, and he is investing the profits in a new and far more elegant eatery called Vivaldi, where a classical pianist in a tuxedo sets the ambiance.

byline.original: By Stephen Kinzer; Stephen Kinzer recently completed five years as The Times's bureau chief in Managua, Nicaragua. He is at work on a book

docs.snippet: LEAD: United States and European negotiators have reached ''a sort of understanding'' on wording intended to break a deadlock over long-term government subsidies to farmers, a spokesman for the European Community said today.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: United States and European negotiators have reached ''a sort of understanding'' on wording intended to break a deadlock over long-term government subsidies to farmers, a spokesman for the European Community said today.

headline.main: Amnesty Looks First at Victims, Not Ideologies

docs.snippet: LEAD: Ending a stalemate in international trade talks, negotiators at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed in principle today to curb Government farm subsidies and agricultural import barriers.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Ending a stalemate in international trade talks, negotiators at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed in principle today to curb Government farm subsidies and agricultural import barriers.

headline.main: GATT Farm Accord To Freeze Subsidies

byline.original: By BURTON BOLLAG, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: More than 80 trading nations today adopted negotiating guidelines for textiles, agriculture, and two other areas, clearing the way for the resumption of suspended international trade talks.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: More than 80 trading nations today adopted negotiating guidelines for textiles, agriculture, and two other areas, clearing the way for the resumption of suspended international trade talks.

headline.main: 80 Nations Clear Way to Resume Trade Talks
